p: The tradition of making “Lohusa Serbeti” after a birth probably is derived from Byzantine birth tradition (custom) where what was called “lochozema,” a nourishing broth, was given to new mothers [ 2, 3]. It is mentioned in ceremonial books that after the birth of an imperial child “Porphyrogenitus” and in one-week-long period of celebration, the preparation of “lochozema,” a nutritious “childbed soup like” broth, was offered in Constantinople's main streets. Then, as birth custom, it was given to all new mothers, to aid milk production and recovery [ 4, 5].
